Maame Ama Bainson

I am currently pursuing my PhD in Mathematical Modelling, Analysis, and Computation at the Maxwell Institute for Mathematical Sciences, a joint centre between the University of Edinburgh and Heriot-Watt University.

My current research focuses on stochastic modelling of disease dynamics, using WKB approximation and Hamiltonian systems to estimate mean persistence times of endemic diseases under Prof. Damian Clancy.

Prior to this, I earned an MSc in Mathematical Sciences with distinction from the African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS Ghana), where my thesis explored forward-backward stochastic differential equations with jumps.

Research

My research lies at the intersection of stochastic modelling, mathematical biology, and dynamical systems, with a focus on understanding and designing eradication policies for endemic diseases through probabilistic and analytical tools.

A central theme of my work is understanding how rare events—such as disease extinction—can be predicted and quantified in complex, noisy systems. I am especially interested in how advanced mathematical methods, like WKB approximation and Hamiltonian systems, can inform real-world public health strategies. Some research questions I am currently exploring include:

  • How can we use stochastic analysis to estimate the persistence time of endemic diseases in a population?
  • What insights can Hamiltonian structures provide about transitions in noisy epidemiological systems?
  • How can mathematical modelling inform the design of optimal eradication strategies under uncertainty?

Below are representative of my academic research experiences and ongoing project:

Eradication Policies for Endemic Diseases

Maame Ama Bainson, Maxwell Institute for Mathematical Sciences

Ongoing PhD Research Project, 2025
Stochastic Modelling WKB Approximation Epidemiology

Working under the supervision of Prof. Damian Clancy, we study the persistence of endemic diseases by applying the Wentzel–Kramers–Brillouin (WKB) approximation to stochastic systems representing disease dynamics. By transforming the system into a Hamiltonian framework, we estimate the mean time until disease extinction, providing insights into eradication strategies in public health policy.

Enhancing Markov Chain Forecasting in Mixed Martial Arts (MMA)

Maame Ama Bainson, Maxwell Institute for Mathematical Sciences

PhD Industrial Project March, 2024
Markov Models Sports Analytics Stamina Modelling

This project developed a refined Markov chain model for predicting outcomes in MMA bouts by incorporating round-by-round performance and introducing a stamina/fatigue coefficient. The model better captures how outcomes evolve over time, improving predictive power and interpretability in performance analytics.

Stochastic Optimal Control with Filtering

Maame Ama Bainson, Maxwell Institute for Mathematical Sciences

PhD Taster Project December, 2023
Stochastic Filtering Optimal Investment Financial Modelling

We tackled an optimal investment problem under partial information using stochastic filtering theory. The framework considered only observable asset prices and volatilities, aiming to maximize returns with incomplete knowledge of market dynamics—a common challenge in quantitative finance.

Forward‐Backward Stochastic Differential Equations with Jumps

Maame Ama Bainson, AIMS Ghana

Master's Thesis July, 2023
Stochastic Differential Equations Jumps Theoretical Analysis

This thesis revisited results from Shamarova and Pereira on fully coupled forward–backward stochastic differential equations (FBSDEs) with jumps. I reproduced key proofs on existence and uniqueness, and explored their connections to classical solutions of nonlocal quasilinear parabolic partial differential equations.

Teaching & Outreach

I’ve been fortunate to learn from inspiring educators and mentors throughout my academic journey, and I’m committed to giving back through teaching and outreach—especially by supporting students from underrepresented communities in mathematics. This section highlights some of my recent efforts in academic instruction and public engagement.

Undergraduate Course Assistant (UCA): Heriot-Watt University, Spring 2025 – Present

As part of my PhD training, I serve as a course assistant, where I support undergraduate students primarily in Statistics and Mathematical Biology. My responsibilities include leading tutorial sessions, organizing lab exercises, and offering one-on-one academic support to help students deepen their conceptual understanding and develop their problem-solving skills.

Volunteer: Maths Outreach Team, University of Edinburgh, Fall 2023 – Present

As a volunteer with the School of Mathematics, I participate in public engagement events designed to make mathematics more accessible and exciting. This includes developing and delivering interactive activities at local schools and public festivals, often aimed at young learners and families. I’m especially passionate about showing that math can be creative, relevant, and fun—no matter your background.
